#Text=Abraham Hooke
#Text=Abraham
#Text=Hooke
#Text=was a wealthy slave merchant from Bristol who participated in the Transatlantic Slave Trade from 1703 to 1736 .
#Text=Personal life
#Text=Abraham Hooke was made a Warden of the Society of Merchant Ventures of Bristol in 1702 , and retained the position in 1703 , the year of his first slave trade .

#Text=He was made the master or the head of the Society of Merchants in 1712 , and was part of the group of men from this society that inherited land and property from the will of Edward Colston in 1708 .
#Text=Hooke was made sheriff of Bristol in 1706 .

#Text=In 1711 , with help from Nathaniel Wade ( a conspirator in the assassination attempt against King Charles II of England ) , Hooke helped fund a bridge in Bristol over the River Frome named " Traitors Bridge " . [ 1 ]

column1: #Text=In 1722 Hooke co-founded Stokes ' Croft Endowed School , one of the oldest endowed schools in Bristol . [ 2 ]

#Text=He had at least one son named Andrew , who wrote a history of Bristol called Bristolia in 1748 , had a doctorate in medicine , was a manager of a printing office in Bristol , and was part of the commission of the peace for Gloucestershire . [ 3 ]
#Text=Family
#Text=Hooke grew up far from impoverished .
#Text=His great-grandfather , Humphrey Hooke , was the sheriff of Bristol in 1614 and mayor in 1629 .
#Text=Abraham ’s grandfather , Thomas , went on to be sheriff in 1634 .
#Text=The merchant ’s father , Sir Humphrey , was also a merchant , and was mayor in 1643 .
#Text=He was elected by the city along with John Knight as Burgess who represented them in Parliament in 1661 , though Hooke requested Lord Ossory be placed in his stead .
#Text=When Ossory was called onto the King ’s private council , Humphrey was placed in his elected position , and was knighted for his courtesy .
#Text=Upon his death in 1677 , he donated 680 British Pounds to St. Stephen Parish , where 8 shillings in bread a week was to be distributed at Queen Elizabeth ’s Hospital . [ 3 ]

#Text=Sir Humphrey is noted as having built Ashley court on Ashley down for a residence , as well as owning another mansion on Corn street and a country residence in Kingsweston which would go on to be remodeled as the Kings Weston House after being sold in 1679 to Sir Robert Southwell . [ 4 ]
#Text=It is likely that Abraham inherited at least one or all three of these locations and resided in them , though it is unlikely that they exist to this day . [ 3 ]
#Text=Transatlantic Slave Trade
#Text=Pickups
#Text=Abraham Hooke 's ships often sailed to the Bite of Biafra which is in the Gulf of Guinea .
#Text=The merchant and his company sent the ships Anna and Sarah , Rebecca and the Tiverton to the Bight of Biafra and the Gulf of Guinea Islands .
#Text=Another popular place his ships traveled to was Gambia .
#Text=The Gambia
#Text=was one of the most popular places for merchants like Hooke to acquire their human cargo because of its geographical locale and proximity to Bristol and the New World .
#Text=Shorter distances traveled aboard these sailing vessels meant fewer deaths among the slaves during the middle passage .
#Text=Because of this , however , Gambian slaves were more expensive .
#Text=Thus slave merchants such as Abraham Hooke were often willing to travel further along the coast of West Africa , places like the Bite of Biafra , to purchase slaves for less money .
#Text=Drop offs
#Text=Abraham Hooke 's slave ships dropped off most of his human cargo in the Caribbean , in places like Jamaica .
#Text=Hooke 's merchant ships dropped off slaves to feed the islands demand for labor , sugar being plantation owner 's main cash crop .
#Text=During that time , Jamaica was under English rule and Jamaican elites were financially bound to England .
#Text=Because of the ties between Jamaica and England , Hooke , as well as other merchants , dropped off many of their slaves in Jamaica . [ 5 ]
#Text=Hooke 's captains also sold slaves in Barbados to owners of the numerous sugar plantations , helping to create one of the most profitable sugar plantation systems in the world . [ 6 ]
#Text=Personal ventures
#Text=Hooke ’s own ventures in slave-trading began in 1703 , when the Cowslip brought 128 African slaves to Jamaica .
#Text=There was a decade hiatus before he continued to traffic humans , having regular ventures from 1713 all the way to 1729 .
#Text=There , there is another hiatus , ending in 1736 when the Betty Snow brought 400 slaves ( the largest haul in a single voyage funded by Hooke ) to be sold in Virginia .
#Text=In total , Hooke would engage in the transport of 5,976 Africans to be sold into slavery over the course of 27 known voyages , 4,828 of whom would survive the Trans-Atlantic crossing .
#Text=This means the fatality rate aboard his ships was 19.3 % , a fair amount greater than the average of 15 % during the early eighteenth century .
#Text=Oftentimes , once the ships had unloaded their human cargo , they would load up on a product in the New World to be sold in the Old .
#Text=In particular , Hooke ’s ships transported a notable amount of redwood , with some “ Guinea grains ” being imported in his earlier voyages . [ 7 ]
